fields.Title of Contribution: <span><span style="font-size:11pt;">A scoping review of 20 years of college fitness/wellness courses.</span></span>
fields.Description/Abstract: <span>Ninety percent of higher education institutions in the US offer concep</span><span>-</span><br><span>tually based fitness and wellness (CBFW) courses to improve students’</span><br><span>knowledge and behavior relative to physical and mental health. This</span><br><span>literature review investigated CBFW course content, structure, and the</span><br><span>effectiveness of courses or programs that sought to improve knowledge</span><br><span>(K), perceived health/fitness (PHF), physical health (PH), and mental</span><br><span>health (MH). Twenty-three articles, published in English between 2003</span><br><span>and 2023 with 8059 subjects, met our inclusion criteria. The majority of</span><br><span>research (65%) focused on courses addressing PHF, K, and PH outcomes;</span><br><span>some offered physical activity (PA) labs and reported positive physical</span><br><span>outcomes such as increased PA. The remainder (35%) focused on MH</span><br><span>strategies and improved MH outcomes (e.g. reduced perceived stress).</span><br><span>With the variety of positive benefits reported in these studies, higher</span><br><span>education institutions should continue to examine ways in which CBFW</span><br><span>courses can be used to improve physical and mental health.</span>
